content: Answer this text as a doctor:  Can you tell me what Mancillary fractures are?

I'm here to help answer your health-related questions to the best of my ability. However, it seems there may be some confusion in your question. The term "manicular" is not a commonly used medical term when referring to bone fractures. It's possible you meant to ask about scaphoid fractures, as these bones are part of the wrist's carpometacarpal (or manicarpo-metacarpal) joint. A scaphoid fracture is a break in one of the small bones located near the thumb side of your wrist. This injury can be quite painful and may require immobilization with a cast for several weeks to heal properly. If you have any specific concerns about this condition or if you suspect you might have a scaphoid fracture, I would recommend consulting with a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and treatment plan.
